crate_groups.name: Common
crate_groups.description: Very commonly used crates that everyone should know about

recommendations.name: rand
recommendations.notes: De facto standard random number generation library split out from the standard library

recommendations.name: fastrand
recommendations.notes: A simple and fast random number generator (but not cryptographically secure).

purposes.name: Time & Date
purposes.notes:
Unfortunately there is no clear answer as to which is best between time and chrono.
Evaluate for yourself between these two, but be resassured that both are trusted and well-maintained.

recommendations.name: time
recommendations.notes: A smaller, simpler library. Preferable if covers your needs, but it's quite limited in what it provides.

recommendations.name: chrono
recommendations.notes: The most comprehensive and full-featured datetime library, but more complex because of it.

recommendations.name: regex
recommendations.notes: De facto standard regex library. Very fast, but does not support fancier features such as backtracking.

recommendations.name: fancy-regex
recommendations.notes: Use if need features such as backtracking which regex doesn't support

recommendations.name: uuid
recommendations.notes: Implements generating and parsing UUIDs and a number of utility functions

recommendations.name: tempfile
recommendations.notes: Supports both temporary files and temporary directories

recommendations.name: flate2
recommendations.notes: Uses a pure-Rust implementation by default. Use feature flags to opt in to system zlib.

recommendations.name: indexmap
recommendations.notes: A HashMap that separately keeps track of insertion order and allows you to efficiently iterate over its elements in that order

recommendations.name: arrayvec
recommendations.notes: Arrays that are ONLY stack-allocated with fixed capacity

recommendations.name: smallvec
recommendations.notes: Arrays that are stack-allocated with fallback to the heap if the fixed stack capacity is exceeded

recommendations.name: tinyvec
recommendations.notes: Stack allocated arrays in 100% safe Rust code but requires items to implement the Default trait.

purposes.name: HTTP Requests
purposes.notes: See the HTTP section below for server-side libraries

recommendations.name: reqwest
recommendations.notes: Full-fat HTTP client. Can be used in both synchronous and asynchronous code. Requires tokio runtime.

recommendations.name: ureq
recommendations.notes: Minimal synchronous HTTP client focussed on simplicity and minimising dependencies.

subgroups.name: Error Handling
subgroups.description: Crates for more easily handling errors

recommendations.name: anyhow
recommendations.notes: Provides a boxed error type that can hold any error, and helpers for generating an application-level stack trace.

recommendations.name: color-eyre
recommendations.notes: A fork of anyhow that gives you more control over the format of the generated error messages. Recommended if you intend to present error messages to end users. Otherwise anyhow is simpler.

purposes.name: For libraries
purposes.notes: See also: Designing error types in Rust

recommendations.name: thiserror
recommendations.notes: Helps with generating boilerplate for enum-style error types.

subgroups.name: Logging
subgroups.description: Crates for logging. Note that in general you will need a separate crate for actually printing/storing the logs

recommendations.name: tracing
recommendations.notes: Tracing is now the go-to crate for logging.

recommendations.name: log
recommendations.notes: An older and simpler crate if your needs are simple and you are not using any async code.

recommendations.name: tracing
recommendations.notes: Tracing is now the go-to crate for logging.

recommendations.name: slog
recommendations.notes: Structured logging

subgroups.name: Language Extensions
subgroups.description: General purpose utility crates that extend language and/or stdlib functionality.

purposes.name: Lazy static variable initialization
purposes.notes: This functionality is now included in the standard library

recommendations.name: once_cell
recommendations.notes: Newer crate with more ergonomic API. Has since been adopted into the std library

recommendations.name: lazy_static
recommendations.notes: Older crate. API is less convenient, but crate is stable and maintained.

recommendations.name: itertools
recommendations.notes: A bunch of useful methods on iterators that aren't in the stdlib

recommendations.name: syn
recommendations.notes: Parse rust source code

recommendations.name: quote
recommendations.notes: Quasi quoting rust (useful for interpolating generated code with literal code)

recommendations.name: paste
recommendations.notes: Concatenating and manipulating identifiers

recommendations.name: darling
recommendations.notes: Derive macro to easily parse derive macro inputs

recommendations.name: bitflags
recommendations.notes: Strongly typed bitflag types

subgroups.name: Serialization
subgroups.description: Encode/decode between in-memory representations and general-purpose wire formats

recommendations.name: serde
recommendations.notes: De facto standard serialization library. Use in conjunction with sub-crates like `serde_json` for the specific format that you are using (JSON, YAML, etc). Supports a variety of both text and binary protocols, including self-describing ones.

recommendations.name: prost
recommendations.notes: Protocol buffer library with strong ergonomics and wide industry adoption. Commonly used with gRPC / `tonic`. Use in conjunction with `protox` to avoid dependency on `protoc`.

recommendations.name: capnp
recommendations.notes: Cap'n Proto library. Offers zero-copy usage mode that is optimal for large messages, along with other improvements over Protocol Buffers. Tradeoffs are less wide usage and less developer-friendly.

recommendations.name: flatbuffers
recommendations.notes: Flatbuffers library. Also offers zero-copy usage and is more widely used than cap'n proto, with further cost to ergonomics.

recommendations.name: postcard
recommendations.notes: no_std focused Serde serializer/deserializer, aimed at constrained environments.

recommendations.name: rkyv
recommendations.notes: Fast zero-copy deserialization framework that allows arbitrary field types and safe zero-copy mutation.

recommendations.name: serde_json
recommendations.notes: A fast and flexible library for parsing and generating JSON using Serdeâ€™s powerful data model.

recommendations.name: configparser
recommendations.notes: A simple library for reading and writing INI-style configuration files with section-based key-value pairs.

recommendations.name: toml
recommendations.notes: A robust TOML parser for Rust, ideal for config files with readable syntax and rich data types.

subgroups.name: System
subgroups.description: For low-level interaction with the underling platform / operating system

recommendations.name: memmap2
recommendations.notes: The older memmap crate is unmaintained.

recommendations.name: libc
recommendations.notes: Bindings for directly calling libc functions.

recommendations.name: windows
recommendations.notes: The official Microsoft-provided crate for interacting with windows APIs

recommendations.name: rustix
recommendations.notes: Efficient and safe POSIX / *nix / Winsock syscall-like APIs. It uses idiomatic Rust types: refs, slices, Results instead of raw pointers, safe wrappers around raw file descriptors, bitflags instead of bare integer flags, and several other conveniences.

recommendations.name: nix
recommendations.notes: Bindings to the various *nix system functions. (Unix, Linux, MacOS, etc.)

recommendations.name: signal-hook
recommendations.notes: Provides high-level, sync APIs for handling signals safely. The low-level machinery is also exposed as a separate crate, signal-hook-registry, which lets other libraries like tokio::signal interoperate with it.

subgroups.name: Tooling
subgroups.description: Developer tools for working with Rust projects.

recommendations.name: rustup
recommendations.notes: Install, manage, and upgrade versions of rustc, cargo, clippy, rustfmt and more.

recommendations.name: clippy
recommendations.notes: The official Rust linter.

recommendations.name: cargo-semver-checks
recommendations.notes: Lint your crate releases for semantic versioning violations.

recommendations.name: rustfmt
recommendations.notes: The official Rust code formatter.

recommendations.name: cross
recommendations.notes: Seamless cross-compiling using Docker containers.

recommendations.name: cargo-zigbuild
recommendations.notes: Easily cross-compile using Zig as the linker.

recommendations.name: cargo-edit
recommendations.notes: Adds 'cargo upgrade' and 'cargo set-version' commands to cargo

recommendations.name: cargo-outdated
recommendations.notes: Finds dependencies that have available updates

recommendations.name: cargo-audit
recommendations.notes: Check dependencies for reported security vulnerabilities

recommendations.name: cargo-license
recommendations.notes: Lists licenses of all dependencies

recommendations.name: cargo-deny
recommendations.notes: Enforce policies on your code and dependencies.

recommendations.name: cargo-nextest
recommendations.notes: Faster, better test runner

recommendations.name: insta
recommendations.notes: Snapshot testing with inline snapshot support

recommendations.name: criterion
recommendations.notes: Statistically accurate benchmarking tool for benchmarking libraries

recommendations.name: divan
recommendations.notes: Simple yet powerful benchmarking library with allocation profiling

recommendations.name: hyperfine
recommendations.notes: Tool for benchmarking compiled binaries (similar to unix time command but better)

recommendations.name: cargo-flamegraph
recommendations.notes: Execution flamegraph generation

recommendations.name: dhat
recommendations.notes: Heap memory profiling

recommendations.name: cargo-show-asm
recommendations.notes: Print the generated assembly for a Rust function

purposes.name: Debugging Macros
purposes.notes: Rust Analyzer also allows you to expand macros directly in your editor

recommendations.name: cargo-expand
recommendations.notes: Allows you to inspect the code that macros expand to

recommendations.name: cargo-release
recommendations.notes: Helper for publishing new crate versions.

recommendations.name: Release-plz
recommendations.notes: Release Rust crates from CI with a Release PR.

recommendations.name: rust-toolchain (github action)
recommendations.notes: Github action to install Rust components via rustup

recommendations.name: rust-cache (github action)
recommendations.notes: Github action to cache compilation artifacts and speed up subsequent runs.

recommendations.name: install-action (github action)
recommendations.notes: GitHub Action for installing development tools (mainly from GitHub Releases).

crate_groups.name: Math / Scientific
crate_groups.description: The num crate is trusted and has a variety of numerical functionality that is missing from the standard library.

recommendations.name: num-traits
recommendations.notes: Traits like Number, Add, etc that allow you write functions that are generic over the specific numeric type

recommendations.name: num-bigint
recommendations.notes: It's not the fastest, but it's part of the trusted num library.

recommendations.name: rug
recommendations.notes: LGPL licensed. Wrapper for GMP. Much faster than num-bigint.

recommendations.name: rust_decimal
recommendations.notes: The binary representation consists of a 96 bit integer number, a scaling factor used to specify the decimal fraction and a 1 bit sign.

recommendations.name: ordered-float
recommendations.notes: Float types that don't allow NaN and are therefore orderable. You can also use the total_cmp method from the standard library like .sort_by(|a, b| a.total_cmp(&b)).

recommendations.name: nalgebra
recommendations.notes: General-purpose linear algebra library with transformations and statically-sized or dynamically-sized matrices. However it supports only vectors (1d) and matrices (2d) and not higher-dimensional tensors.

recommendations.name: ndarray
recommendations.notes: Less featureful than nalgebra but supports arbitrarily dimensioned arrays

recommendations.name: polars
recommendations.notes: Similar to the Pandas library in Python but in pure Rust. Uses the Apache Arrow Columnar Format as the memory model.

recommendations.name: datafusion
recommendations.notes: Apache DataFusion is an in-memory query engine that uses Apache Arrow as the memory model

crate_groups.name: FFI / Interop
crate_groups.description: Crates that allow Rust to interact with code written in other languages.

recommendations.name: bindgen
recommendations.notes: Generate Rust bindings to C libraries

recommendations.name: cbindgen
recommendations.notes: Generate C bindings to Rust libraries

recommendations.name: cc
recommendations.notes: Compile and link C code as part of your Cargo build

recommendations.name: cxx
recommendations.notes: Safe C++ <-> Rust interop by generating code for both sides.

recommendations.name: pyo3
recommendations.notes: Supports both calling python code from Rust and exposing Rust code to Python

recommendations.name: napi
recommendations.notes: is a framework for building pre-compiled Node.js addons in Rust.

recommendations.name: neon
recommendations.notes: Slower than napi, but also widely used and well-maintained

recommendations.name: magnus
recommendations.notes: Ruby bindings for Rust. Write Ruby extension gems in Rust, or call Ruby from Rust. Supported by Ruby's rubygems and bundler

recommendations.name: rutie
recommendations.notes: Supports both embedding Rust into Ruby applications and embedding Ruby into Rust applications

recommendations.name: objc2
recommendations.notes: Sound and Idiomatic Rust to Objective-C interface and runtime bindings. Main crate in the objc2 project.

see_also.name: objc
see_also.notes: Older non-idiomatic bindings crate. Has been superseded by objc2.

recommendations.name: jni
recommendations.notes: Implement Java methods for JVM and Android in Rust. Call Java code from Rust. Embed JVM in Rust applications.

recommendations.name: mlua
recommendations.notes: Bindings to Lua 5.4, 5.3, 5.2, 5.1 (including LuaJIT)

recommendations.name: flutter_rust_bridge
recommendations.notes: Works with Dart with or without Flutter

recommendations.name: rustler
recommendations.notes: Safe Rust bridge for creating Erlang NIF functions

recommendations.name: uniffi
recommendations.notes: Share Rust codebase to create cross-platform apps (also 3rd party support for Kotlin Multiplatform, Go, C#, Dart)

crate_groups.name: Cryptography
crate_groups.description: Crates that provide implementations of cryptographic algorithms. This section attempts to list the best crates for the listed algorithms, but does not intend to make recommendations for the algorithms themselves.

purposes.name: Password Hashing
purposes.notes: For more algorithms, see Rust Crypto Password Hashes.

purposes.name: General Purpose Hashing
purposes.notes: For more algorithms, see Rust Crypto Hashes.

purposes.name: AEAD Encryption
purposes.notes: For more algorithms, see Rust Crypto AEADs.

purposes.name: Digital Signatures
purposes.notes: For more algorithms, see Rust Crypto Signatures.

recommendations.name: ed25519
recommendations.notes: Use in conjunction with the ed25519-dalek crate.

purposes.name: Certificate Formats
purposes.notes: For more formats, see Rust Crypto Formats.

recommendations.name: rustls
recommendations.notes: Rustls is a modern TLS library that aims to provide a good level of cryptographic security and no unsafe features or obsolete cryptography by default.

recommendations.name: native-tls
recommendations.notes: Delegates to the system TLS implementations on windows and macOS, and uses OpenSSL on linux.

see_also.name: webpki
see_also.notes: X.509 Certificate validation. Builds on top of ring.

see_also.name: ring
see_also.notes: Fork of BoringSSL. Provides low-level cryptographic primitives for TLS/SSL

recommendations.name: subtle
recommendations.notes: Utilities for writing constant-time algorithms

recommendations.name: zeroize
recommendations.notes: Securely erase memory

crate_groups.name: Networking
crate_groups.description: TCP, HTTP, GRPc, etc. And the executors required to do asynchronous networking.

subgroups.name: Async Foundations
subgroups.description: To do async programming using the async-await in Rust you need a runtime to execute drive your Futures.

recommendations.name: tokio
recommendations.notes: The oldest async runtime in the Rust ecosystem and still the most widely supported. Recommended for new projects.

recommendations.name: futures-executor
recommendations.notes: A minimal executor. In particular, the block_on function is useful if you want to run an async function synchronously in codebase that is mostly synchronous.

recommendations.name: smol
recommendations.notes: A small and modular async runtime. Since the implementation is modularized in smaller crates, you can directly use only the required crates instead of depending on the entire runtime.

recommendations.name: futures
recommendations.notes: Utility functions for working with Futures and Streams

recommendations.name: async-trait
recommendations.notes: Provides a workaround for the lack of language support for async functions in traits

recommendations.name: glommio
recommendations.notes: Use if you need io_uring support. Still somewhat experimental but rapidly maturing.

subgroups.name: HTTP
subgroups.description: HTTP client and server libraries, as well as lower-level building blocks.

recommendations.name: http
recommendations.notes: The `http` crate doesn't actually contain an HTTP implementation. Just types and interfaces to help interoperability.

recommendations.name: hyper
recommendations.notes: A low-level HTTP implementation (both client and server). Implements HTTP/1, and HTTP/2. Works best with the tokio async runtime, but can support other runtimes.

recommendations.name: reqwest
recommendations.notes: Full-fat HTTP client. Can be used in both synchronous and asynchronous code. Requires tokio runtime.

recommendations.name: ureq
recommendations.notes: Minimal synchronous HTTP client focussed on simplicity and minimising dependencies.

recommendations.name: axum
recommendations.notes: A minimal and ergonomic framework. An official part of the tokio project. Recommend for most new projects.

recommendations.name: actix-web
recommendations.notes: A performance focussed framework. All Rust frameworks are fast, but choose actix-web if you need the absolutely maximum performance.

see_also.name: rocket
see_also.notes: Has an excellent API and a solid implementation. However development has been intermittent.

see_also.name: warp
see_also.notes: Very similar to axum but with a quirkier API. This is a solid framework, but you should probably prefer Axum unless you particularly like the API

see_also.name: tide
see_also.notes: Similar to Axum, but based on async-std rather than tokio

recommendations.name: async-graphql
recommendations.notes: A high-performance graphql server library that's fully specification compliant. Integrates with actix-web, axum, poem, rocket, tide, warp.

subgroups.name: Websockets
subgroups.description: This section includes libraries for you to use just websockets. However note that many of the HTTP server frameworks in the section above also support websockets

recommendations.name: tungstenite
recommendations.notes: Low-level crate that others build on

recommendations.name: tokio-tungstenite
recommendations.notes: If you are using the tokio executor

recommendations.name: async-tungstenite
recommendations.notes: If you are using the async-std executor

recommendations.name: tonic
recommendations.notes: gRPC over HTTP/2 with full support for asynchronous code. Works with tokio

subgroups.name: D-Bus
subgroups.description: For cross-platform D-Bus clients and services.

recommendations.name: zbus
recommendations.notes: A Rust-only (a)sync implementation of the protocol. Provides high-level proxies and zbus_xmlgen for scaffolding. Includes a book for D-Bus/zbus beginners.

recommendations.name: dbus
recommendations.notes: Bindings for the battle-tested libdbus implementation. Has sister crates for asynchrony, codegen, etc.

subgroups.name: SQL Databases
subgroups.description: The multi-database options (SQLx and Diesel) are generally quite good, and worth considering even if you only need support for a single database.

recommendations.name: sqlx
recommendations.notes:
Works with Postgres, MySQL, SQLite, and MS SQL.
Supports compile time checking of queries. Async: supports both tokio and async-std.

recommendations.name: diesel
recommendations.notes: Has excellent performance and takes an approach of strict compile time guarantees. The main crate is Sync only, but diesel-async provides an async connection implementation.

recommendations.name: sea-orm
recommendations.notes: Built on top of sqlx (see above). There is also a related sea-query crate that provides a query builder without full ORM functionality.

recommendations.name: tokio-postgres
recommendations.notes: Postgres-specific library. Performs better than SQLx

recommendations.name: mysql_async
recommendations.notes: Has a poorly designed API. Prefer SQLx or Diesel for MySQL

recommendations.name: rusqlite
recommendations.notes: Provides a sync API to SQLite + provides access to advanced sqlite features.

recommendations.name: tiberius
recommendations.notes: MS SQL specific library. Has better support for advanced column types than SQLx.

recommendations.name: diesel-oci
recommendations.notes: Diesel backend and connection implementation for oracle databases

recommendations.name: oracle
recommendations.notes: Rust bindings to ODPI-C

recommendations.name: sibyl
recommendations.notes: An OCI-based interface supporting both blocking (threads) and nonblocking (async) AP

purposes.name: LMDB
purposes.notes: The rkv crate depends on the lmdb-rkv dependency which is archived and is inactive.

recommendations.name: heed
recommendations.notes: A fully typed LMDB wrapper with minimum overhead.

recommendations.name: cassandra-protocol
recommendations.notes: Low-level Cassandra protocol implementation.

recommendations.name: cdrs-tokio
recommendations.notes: High-level async Cassandra driver.

recommendations.name: deadpool
recommendations.notes: A dead simple async pool for connections and objects of any type.

subgroups.name: Argument Parsing
subgroups.description: See argparse-benchmarks-rs for a full comparison of the crates mentioned here and more.

recommendations.name: clap
recommendations.notes: Ergonomic, battle-tested, includes the kitchen sink, and is fast at runtime. However compile times can be slow

see_also.name: bpaf
see_also.notes: Faster compile times than clap while still being featureful. But still has some rough edges, and the API can be confusing at times.

recommendations.name: lexopt
recommendations.notes: Fast compile times, fast runtime, pedantic about correctness. API is less ergonomic

recommendations.name: pico-args
recommendations.notes: Fast compile times, fast runtime, more lax about correctness. API is more ergonomic

subgroups.name: Utility
subgroups.description: Helpers that are often useful when implementing CLIs

recommendations.name: globset
recommendations.notes: High-performance globbing that allows multiple globs to be evaluated at once

recommendations.name: walkdir
recommendations.notes: Basic recursive filesystem walking.

recommendations.name: ignore
recommendations.notes: Recursive filesystem walking that respects ignore files (like .gitignore)

recommendations.name: notify
recommendations.notes: Watch files or directories and execute a function when they change

recommendations.name: dirs
recommendations.notes: Provide platform-specific locations for configuration, cache, and other data

recommendations.name: directories
recommendations.notes: A higher-level library that can also compute paths for applications

see_also.name: etcetera
see_also.notes: An alternative with a different license

subgroups.name: Terminal Rendering
subgroups.description: For fancy terminal rendering and TUIs. The crates recommended here work cross-platform (including windows).

recommendations.name: termcolor
recommendations.notes: Cross-platform terminal colour output

recommendations.name: indicatif
recommendations.notes: Progress bars and spinners

recommendations.name: ratatui
recommendations.notes: A high-level TUI library with widgets, layout, etc.

recommendations.name: crossterm
recommendations.notes: Low-level cross-platform terminal rendering and event handling

recommendations.name: inquire
recommendations.notes: Ask for confirmation, selection, text input and more

recommendations.name: parking_lot
recommendations.notes: std::sync::Mutex also works fine. But Parking Lot is faster.

recommendations.name: arc-swap
recommendations.notes: Useful for sharing data that has many readers but few writers

purposes.name: Concurrent HashMap
purposes.notes: See conc-map-bench for comparative benchmarks of concurrent HashMaps.

recommendations.name: dashmap
recommendations.notes: The fastest for general purpose workloads

recommendations.name: papaya
recommendations.notes: Particularly good for read-heavy workloads.

purposes.name: Channels
purposes.notes: See communicating-between-sync-and-async-code for notes on when to use async-specific channels vs general purpose channels.

recommendations.name: crossbeam-channel
recommendations.notes: The same channel algorithm as in the standard library but with a more powerful API, offering a Go-like 'select' feature.

recommendations.name: flume
recommendations.notes: Smaller and simpler than crossbeam-channel and almost as fast

recommendations.name: tokio
recommendations.notes: Tokio's sync module provides channels for using in async code

recommendations.name: postage
recommendations.notes: Channels that integrate nicely with async code, with different options than Tokio

recommendations.name: rayon
recommendations.notes: Convert sequential computation into parallel computation with one call - `par_iter` instead of `iter`

recommendations.name: gtk4
recommendations.notes: Rust bindings to GTK4. These are quite well supported, although you'll often need to use the C documentation.

recommendations.name: relm4
recommendations.notes: A higher-level library that sits on top of gtk4-rs

recommendations.name: tauri
recommendations.notes: Electron-like web-based UI. Except it uses system webviews rather than shipping chromium, and non-UI code is written in Rust rather than node.js

recommendations.name: dioxus
recommendations.notes: A very nice API layer that has Tauri, Web, and TUI renderers. A native renderer is coming soon.

recommendations.name: egui
recommendations.notes: Immediate-mode UI with lots of widgets. Very useable out of the box if your needs are simple and you don't need to customise the look and feel

recommendations.name: iced
recommendations.notes: Retained mode UI with a nice API. It's useable for basic apps, but has a number of missing features including multiple windows, layers, and proper text rendering.

recommendations.name: slint
recommendations.notes: A stable and feature-rich UI toolkit with a declarative language. Licensed under GPL, royalty-free for desktop/mobile, or with paid options for proprietary embedded use.

see_also.name: floem
see_also.notes: Inspired by Xilem, Leptos and rui, floem is currently more complete than any of them for native UI. Used by the Lapce text editor.

see_also.name: vizia
see_also.notes: Fairly complete with sophisticated layout and text layout, but has yet to make a stable release.

see_also.name: xilem
see_also.notes: The replacement for Druid based on the more interoperable Vello and Glazier crates. However, it's currently not complete enough to be usable.

see_also.name: freya
see_also.notes: Dioxus-based GUI framework using Skia for rendering.

see_also.name: gpui
see_also.notes: High performance framework used in the Zed text editor. Now available on macOS and linux.

see_also.name: makepad
see_also.notes: Makepad has a strong focus on performance and minimising bloat but is consequently less feature complete in areas such as accessibility and system integration.

recommendations.name: winit
recommendations.notes: The defacto standard option. Uses an event loop based architecture. Widely used and should probably be the default choice.

recommendations.name: tao
recommendations.notes: A fork of winit by the Tauri project which adds support for things like system menus that desktop apps need.

recommendations.name: baseview
recommendations.notes: Specialized window creation library targeting windows to be embedded in other applications (e.g. DAW plugins)

recommendations.name: femtovg
recommendations.notes: OpenGL based. Offers a simple API. Probably the easiest to get started with.

recommendations.name: skia-safe
recommendations.notes: Bindings to the Skia C++ library. The most complete option with excellent performance. However, it can be difficult to get it to compile.

recommendations.name: vello
recommendations.notes: WGPU based and uses cutting edge techniques to render vector paths using the GPU. Still somewhat immature and hasn't yet put out a stable release.

recommendations.name: vger
recommendations.notes: A simpler WGPU based option which is less innovative but currently more stable than vello.

recommendations.name: webrender
recommendations.notes: OpenGL based. Mature with production usage in Firefox but documentation and OSS maintenance are lacking.

recommendations.name: taffy
recommendations.notes: Supports Flexbox and CSS Grid algorithms.

recommendations.name: morphorm
recommendations.notes: Implements it's own layout algorithm based on Subform layout

recommendations.name: cosmic-text
recommendations.notes: Full text layout including rich text and support for BiDi and non-latin scripts. The best option for now.

recommendations.name: parley
recommendations.notes: Another very accomplished text layout library used by Druid/Xilem.

recommendations.name: accesskit
recommendations.notes: Allows you to export a semantic tree representing your UI to make accessible to screen readers and other assistive technologies

recommendations.name: arboard
recommendations.notes: A fork of rust-clipboard that supports copy and pasting of both text and images on Linux (X11/Wayland), MacOS and Windows.

recommendations.name: rfd
recommendations.notes: Platform-native open/save file dialogs. Can be used in conjunction with other UI libraries.

recommendations.name: bevy
recommendations.notes: An ECS based game engine, good for 3D but also capable of 2D.

recommendations.name: fyrox
recommendations.notes: An OOP-focused game engine with 3D and 2D support and a full GUI scene editor.
